results.title: The Killing of Angelo Tsakos
results.brief_description: In 1985, Angelo Tsakos, a young Greek-Australian boy from the depressed western suburbs of Sydney was shot dead while driving a stolen car, by a probationary police constable. He was only sixteen. At the inquiry into the incident, three differing versions of the event were described. This film reconstructs these versions and finds questions still unanswered. His family continue in their efforts to get a full enquiry into the killing of Angelo Tsakos.

results.title: The Killing fields
results.brief_description: David Puttnam brings to the screen an intense and personal story of loyalty, friendship and survival amidst the torment of war and the incredible strength of one man’s will to survive. Based on Pulitzer prize winning correspondent, Sydney Schanberg’s 1980 article “The Death and Life of Dith Pran”, this gripping movie is a factual account of Schanberg’s friendship and professional relationship with his trusted interpreter, trouble-shooter and colleague - Pran - during the turbulent period that saw Cambodia fall to the Khmer Rouge. Stars Sam Waterston and Haing S. Ngor. Film soundtrack music score by Mike Oldfield.

results.title: The Killifish
results.brief_description: A study of the life cycle of the killifish, showing it in streams and ponds, but principally in aquariums. The physical conditions and feed requirements are explained. Egglaying, and the development of the young fish are shown. Uses Photomicroscopy. English commentary, Japanese subtitles.

results.title: The Killer
results.creator_credit: Golden Princess, Film Workshop, Magnum Entertainment, Tsui Hark and John Woo
results.brief_description: Part shoot-em-up action, part Douglas Sirk melodrama, John Woo’s kinetic crime thriller raises the well worn action genre to new and delirious heights. The charismatic Chow Yun Fat stars as the guilt ridden contract killer of the title who experiences a crisis of sorts when he accidentally blinds a night club singer (played by Hong Kong pop star Sally Yeh) during one of his hits. The angsty hitman then spends the rest of the film trying to redeem himself and make enough hits to pay for the singers cornea transplant. Hot on his trail however is Inspector Li (Danny Lee) who subsequently forms a strange affiliation with the killer. Woo, well known for his outrageous and balletic gun play doesn’t disappoint here with an astronomical body count but infuses the film with his other ongoing obsessions, the intimate code and conduct of male bonding and the dual nature of men. Oddly enough this version differs from it’s original release in that the nicknames that Chow Yun Fat and Danny Lee use for each other (Mickey Mouse and Dumbo) have been changed to Butt-head and Numb-nuts. See also: ‘Yang and yin: gender in Chinese cinema: a film to celebrate 100 years of cinema’ by Stanley Kwan (in our collection). In Cantonese with English subtitles. See also ‘Hard-boiled’, ‘Hard Target’, ‘Face-off’, ‘Broken Arrow’.

results.title: The Kill-off
results.creator_credit: Filmworld International Productions, Lydia Dean Pilcher and Maggie Greenwald
results.brief_description: Set in a bleak north-east American beach town, this nihilistic drama circulates around Luane, the bedridden town gossip, who manipulates members of the down-and-out community with her vicious rumour-mongering. Her machinations drive her victims to increasingly desperate acts that cumulate in a final showdown. While the world Greenwald reveals is relentlessly bleak, her portrayal of human sleaze and savagery is achieved by subtle means. She injects Thompson’s novel with a wry black humour and a hint of the surreal.

results.title: The Kidney: the living machine
results.creator_credit: Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education and John Rodgers
results.brief_description: Peter Couchman discusses the function of the human kidney with Professor Graeme Campbell of the Melbourne Zoological Department. Discusses kidney malfunction and how this can be treated by dialysis together with footage of patients undergoing treatment at Prince Henry’s Hospital.

results.title: The Kid; Three men in a tub
results.brief_description: In “the Kid”, Chaplin is less of the buffoon and more of the actor but his comedy is ever present and there is not a dull moment once the comedian comes into the picture. Introduced as “a picture with a smile - perhaps a tear”, it proves to be just that. For while it will move people to uproarious laughter and keep them in a state of uneasing delight, it will also touch their hearts and win sympathy, not only for the star, but for its leading woman and little Jackie Coogan. The little tramp adopts an abandoned Kid in the slums of early New York city, where only the fittest can survive. There are characteristic “Chaplin touches”. A fine instance of imagination is where he dreams of Heaven. His slum alley is transformed into a bit of paradise, where everybody - including his nemesis, the cop, and a big bully are turned into angels! Includes an episode of those mischievious mites, The Young Rascals, entitled “Three men in a tub”.

results.title: The Kid who couldn't miss
results.brief_description: The Kid Who Couldn’t Miss has been the subject of controversy since its release in 1982. It is the fascinating account of how a brash kid from Owen Sound, Ontario, named William Avery (Billy) Bishop, became one of the leading fighter pilots of World War I. This film is a docudrama and combines elements of both reality and fiction. It does not pretend to be a biography of Billy Bishop. Certain characters have been used to express certain doubts and reservations about Bishop’s exploits. There is no evidence that these were shared by the actual characters. At age 23, Bishop became a hero and Canada’s most decorated military figure. Excerpts from John Gray’s play Billy Bishop Goes to War, featuring Eric Peterson, provide a thread throughout the film.

results.title: The Kid Stakes
results.brief_description: One of Australia’s major silent features, ‘The Kid Stakes’ concerns Fatty Finn and his gang. As they are preparing to enter their pet goat, Hector, in the goat-cart race, a member of a rival gang lets Hector escape on the very morning of the race. The adventures of Fatty and the gang in their attempt to rescue Hector are told with charm and humour. As a document of Australian clothes, customs, jokes and appearances of the era, this film is a valuable historical record. Based on Syd Nicholls’ comic strip characters that appeared in the Sydney Sunday News newspaper. Cast includes Ray Salmon, Frank Boyd, Robin Ordell and Charles Roberts. Cinematography by Arthur Higgins.

results.title: The Kid
results.brief_description: The Kid - Dumped in a garbage can, in the roughest part of the slums, a vagabond tramp finds an abandoned baby. No-one in the slums can afford another mouth to feed, but with the ever-watchful policeman around the corner, the tramp is unwittingly compelled to “adopt” the child. In classic style resembling the later “Gold Rush”, Chaplin shows his genius in bringing up baby, from inventing his own hysterical methods of changing nappies, to teaching the grown-up nine year old the art of survival, of self-defence, and earning a living- the Kid smashes windows, while Charlie repairs them cheap! A heart-warming story also unfolds, as the true mother stumbles upon her child - Coogan’s sensational performance made him the best-loved child star of the Golden Era! Cast also includes Edna Purviance, Chuck Riesner, Carl Miller, Henry Bergman. “Three men in a tub” - Alfalfa loses his girl to a smoothie with a yacht, but conspires with his friends to get her back. Featuring the Little Rascals.
